item.title: General Introduction of Tidyverse Series1
item.description:
What is tidyverse?

The tidyverse is an opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science. All packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structures. This is my most favourite R package ecosystem for data manipulation, and is the reason that I still cannot completely get rid of using R.

  • To be more specific, It is a collection of R packages which are designed to be used together.
  • ggplot2, for data visualisation
  • dplyr, for data manipulation
  • tidyr, for data tidying
  • readr, for data import
  • purrr, for functional programming
  • tibble, for tibbles, a modern re-imagining of data frames
  • stringr, for strings
  • forcats, for factors
  • and many other functions

Why tidyverse?

There’re a couple reasons:

  • Base R functons are often slow and the implemenations sometimes are inconsistent.
  • Writing tidyverse function use pip operator %>% is cleaner and more elegant.
  • Lots of convenient functions for data manipulating and warggling helps accelerating data analysis process.

Let’s see five base functions given by dplyr

  • select: picks variables based on their names(Selecr columns). We do not need to add double quote on variable name
  • filter: picks cases based on their values; filter rows with some conditions.
  • mutate: adds new variables that are functions of existing variables
  • arrange: changes the ordering of the rows => reordering helps for data visualization
  • summarize or summarise: reduces multiple values down to a single summary
  • group_by: will group data into different categories, and we can add complicated calculation based on this function.

Obtain some data

First of all, we need some data to work with.

library(tidyverse)
library(nycflights13) # Please intstall this packages which contains some interating dataset.
flights %>% head
## # A tibble: 6 x 19
##    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
##   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
## 1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
## 2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
## 3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
## 4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
## 5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
## 6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
## # ... with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
## #   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>,
## #   air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>,
## #   time_hour <dttm>

Data frame with columns information for flight dataset.

  • year, month, day: Date of departure.

  • dep_time, arr_time: Actual departure and arrival times (format HHMM or HMM), local tz.

  • sched_dep_time, sched_arr_time: Scheduled departure and arrival times (format HHMM or HMM), local tz.

  • dep_delay, arr_delay: Departure and arrival delays, in minutes. Negative times represent early departures/arrivals.

  • carrier: Two letter carrier abbreviation. See airlines to get name.

  • flight: Flight number.

  • tailnum: Plane tail number. See planes for additional metadata.

  • origin, dest: Origin and destination. See airports for additional metadata.

  • air_time: Amount of time spent in the air, in minutes.

  • distance: Distance between airports, in miles.

  • hour, minute: Time of scheduled departure broken into hour and minutes.

  • time_hour: Scheduled date and hour of the flight as a POSIXct date. Along with origin, can be used to join flights data to weather data.

Skimr Package

This is a package used to quickly display summary statistics. Skimr handles different data types and returns a skim_df object which can be included in a tidyverse pipeline or displayed nicely for the human reader. It will shows you a distribution for each variable and outliers which marked with red color.

here I just use subset of the dataset for the purpose of demonstration.

library(skimr)
flight_subset <- flights %>% sample_n(5) # sample_frac, sample_integer
flight_subset %>% skim
Table 1: Data summary
Name Piped data
Number of rows 5
Number of columns 19
_______________________
Column type frequency:
character 4
numeric 14
POSIXct 1
________________________
Group variables None

Variable type: character

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate min max empty n_unique whitespace
carrier 0 1 2 2 0 4 0
tailnum 0 1 6 6 0 5 0
origin 0 1 3 3 0 2 0
dest 0 1 3 3 0 5 0

Variable type: numeric

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate mean sd p0 p25 p50 p75 p100 hist
year 0 1 2013.0 0.00 2013 2013 2013 2013 2013 ▁▁▇▁▁
month 0 1 5.2 2.77 2 4 4 7 9 ▃▇▁▃▃
day 0 1 22.0 5.83 16 17 21 27 29 ▇▃▁▁▇
dep_time 0 1 1512.6 402.85 1004 1444 1449 1536 2130 ▃▇▃▁▃
sched_dep_time 0 1 1493.6 404.02 1003 1435 1450 1450 2130 ▂▇▁▁▂
dep_delay 0 1 11.0 28.08 -6 -1 0 1 61 ▇▁▁▁▂
arr_time 0 1 1694.8 403.66 1138 1611 1627 1850 2248 ▃▁▇▃▃
sched_arr_time 0 1 1693.4 416.04 1134 1634 1652 1744 2303 ▂▁▇▁▂
arr_delay 0 1 1.4 37.89 -25 -23 -15 4 66 ▇▂▁▁▂
flight 0 1 1238.4 1421.28 104 347 353 1995 3393 ▇▁▂▁▂
air_time 0 1 83.6 49.15 46 62 62 79 169 ▇▂▁▁▂
distance 0 1 499.2 326.80 213 301 397 544 1041 ▇▇▁▁▃
hour 0 1 14.6 3.97 10 14 14 14 21 ▂▇▁▁▂
minute 0 1 33.6 19.30 3 30 35 50 50 ▃▁▃▃▇

Variable type: POSIXct

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate min max median n_unique
time_hour 0 1 2013-02-27 14:00:00 2013-09-17 14:00:00 2013-04-29 10:00:00 5

Select functions

You can select columns of the dataset by specifying the name in the select function

flight_subset %>% 
    select(dep_time, arr_time)

flight_subset%>% 
    select(starts_with("arr_"))# specify the start word # ends_with()

flight_subset %>% 
    select(ends_with("_time")) # select all the columns with end word: time

flight_subset %>% 
    select(contains("dep")) # select the columns that contains "dep"

flight_subset %>% 
    select(-contains("dep")) # we can also put negation sign to select columns otherwise `dep`

# flight_subset %>% 
    # select(!contains("dep")) # we cannot use it sine this is not a logical vector, contains("dep")` must evaluate to column positions or names, not a logical vector

# Select use - for negation. While Filter use ! since it is logical operator

flight_subset %>% 
    select(dep_time: arr_time) # from dep_time to arr_time

flight_subset %>% 
    select(dep_time, everything()) # reordering , put the dep_time in the very front
  • Notice that if you just need one single variable, you couls use pull function.
  • And you can use rename to rename your columns variable.

pull function directly gives the vector.

flight_subset %>% 
    pull(dep_time) 
## [1] 1444 1004 2130 1449 1536

Filter Function

flight_subset %>% 
    filter(origin == "JFK") # filter the row with condition

flight_subset %>% 
    filter(distance > 1000)

# note that we are using a single `&` instead of `&&` as in base R
flight_subset %>% 
    filter(origin == "JFK" & distance > 100)

flight_subset %>% 
    filter(distance < 500 | distance > 1000) # this is or logical condition

flight_subset %>%
    filter(!between(distance, 500, 1000)) # since it is logical operator we use ! instead of !

# only keep the complete cases
flight_subset %>% 
    filter(complete.cases(flight_subset)) # This helps detect NA value in each row; use ! for negation

Chaining up function

This is the my favourite part of tidyverse. We can use %>% to chain up functions instead of wrapping up lots of functions together. This helps making code seem more elegant and cleaner. Python also has the chainning ability.

flight_subset %>% 
    select(origin, air_time) %>% 
    filter(origin == "JFK" & air_time > 10) %>% 
    rename(air_time_new = air_time)
## # A tibble: 3 x 2
##   origin air_time_new
##   <chr>         <dbl>
## 1 JFK              62
## 2 JFK              46
## 3 JFK             169

Some more Example

In this example we first select origin and air_time, and we filter out the row when origin == "JFK" and air_time < mean(air_time). Here mean(air_time) is the mean of air_time in the flight_subset

flight_subset %>% 
    select(origin, air_time) %>% 
    filter(origin == "JFK", air_time < mean(air_time, na.rm = TRUE )) #compare the mean with air_time in flight_subset
## # A tibble: 2 x 2
##   origin air_time
##   <chr>     <dbl>
## 1 JFK          62
## 2 JFK          46

If it is difficult to understand, we can sperate above into two steps. And below gives the same result.

# Step 1
mean_air_time = flight_subset %>% 
    pull(air_time) %>% 
    mean(na.rm = TRUE)

# Step 2
flight_subset %>% 
    select(origin, air_time) %>% 
    filter(origin == "JFK", air_time < mean_air_time) 
## # A tibble: 2 x 2
##   origin air_time
##   <chr>     <dbl>
## 1 JFK          62
## 2 JFK          46

we can use . to represent the working data frame. These two below are the same

flight_subset %>% 
    filter(complete.cases(.))
## # A tibble: 5 x 19
##    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
##   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
## 1  2013     9    17     1444           1450        -6     1627
## 2  2013     4    29     1004           1003         1     1138
## 3  2013     4    16     2130           2130         0     2248
## 4  2013     7    21     1449           1450        -1     1611
## 5  2013     2    27     1536           1435        61     1850
## # ... with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
## #   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>,
## #   air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>,
## #   time_hour <dttm>
flight_subset %>% 
    filter(complete.cases(flight_subset))
## # A tibble: 5 x 19
##    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
##   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
## 1  2013     9    17     1444           1450        -6     1627
## 2  2013     4    29     1004           1003         1     1138
## 3  2013     4    16     2130           2130         0     2248
## 4  2013     7    21     1449           1450        -1     1611
## 5  2013     2    27     1536           1435        61     1850
## # ... with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
## #   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>,
## #   air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>,
## #   time_hour <dttm>

item.title: Tidyverse Join Function Part-2
item.description:
In the Part1 Introducton for Join function family in tidyverse family, we explored some useful functions by exploring some toy examples. In this post, we go further with some slightly more complicated dataset. By doing so helps us have a deeper unstanding how join family works.

First part will just go over the function a liitle bit with a different dataset, and second part will practice in the more complicated datasets.

library(tidyverse)

The Data

superheroes <- tibble::tribble(
       ~name, ~alignment,  ~gender,          ~publisher,
   "Magneto",      "bad",   "male",            "Marvel",
     "Storm",     "good", "female",            "Marvel",
  "Mystique",      "bad", "female",            "Marvel",
    "Batman",     "good",   "male",                "DC",
     "Joker",      "bad",   "male",                "DC",
  "Catwoman",      "bad", "female",                "DC",
   "Hellboy",     "good",   "male", "Dark Horse Comics"
  )

publishers <- tibble::tribble(
  ~publisher, ~yr_founded,
        "DC",       1934L,
    "Marvel",       1939L,
     "Image",       1992L
  )

superheroes
## # A tibble: 7 x 4
##   name     alignment gender publisher        
##   <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <chr>            
## 1 Magneto  bad       male   Marvel           
## 2 Storm    good      female Marvel           
## 3 Mystique bad       female Marvel           
## 4 Batman   good      male   DC               
## 5 Joker    bad       male   DC               
## 6 Catwoman bad       female DC               
## 7 Hellboy  good      male   Dark Horse Comics
publishers
## # A tibble: 3 x 2
##   publisher yr_founded
##   <chr>          <int>
## 1 DC              1934
## 2 Marvel          1939
## 3 Image           1992

Inner Join

As a reminder, inner_join(x, y) returns all matched rows and columns between x and y tables. Notice that rows from publishers will duplicate themselves for matching the rows from superheros in this case.

superheroes %>%
    inner_join(publishers, by = "publisher")
## # A tibble: 6 x 5
##   name     alignment gender publisher yr_founded
##   <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <chr>          <int>
## 1 Magneto  bad       male   Marvel          1939
## 2 Storm    good      female Marvel          1939
## 3 Mystique bad       female Marvel          1939
## 4 Batman   good      male   DC              1934
## 5 Joker    bad       male   DC              1934
## 6 Catwoman bad       female DC              1934

Left Join

left_join(x, y): Return all rows from x, and all columns from x and y. If there are multiple matches between x and y, all combination of the matches are returned. This is a mutating join.

superheroes
## # A tibble: 7 x 4
##   name     alignment gender publisher        
##   <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <chr>            
## 1 Magneto  bad       male   Marvel           
## 2 Storm    good      female Marvel           
## 3 Mystique bad       female Marvel           
## 4 Batman   good      male   DC               
## 5 Joker    bad       male   DC               
## 6 Catwoman bad       female DC               
## 7 Hellboy  good      male   Dark Horse Comics
publishers
## # A tibble: 3 x 2
##   publisher yr_founded
##   <chr>          <int>
## 1 DC              1934
## 2 Marvel          1939
## 3 Image           1992
superheroes %>%
    left_join(publishers, by = "publisher")
## # A tibble: 7 x 5
##   name     alignment gender publisher         yr_founded
##   <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <chr>                  <int>
## 1 Magneto  bad       male   Marvel                  1939
## 2 Storm    good      female Marvel                  1939
## 3 Mystique bad       female Marvel                  1939
## 4 Batman   good      male   DC                      1934
## 5 Joker    bad       male   DC                      1934
## 6 Catwoman bad       female DC                      1934
## 7 Hellboy  good      male   Dark Horse Comics         NA

Semi join

semi_join(x, y): Return all rows from x where there are matching values in y, keeping just columns from x. A semi join differs from an inner join because an inner join will return one row of x for each matching row of y, where a semi join will never duplicate rows of x. This is a filtering join.

Recall that superheros is the baseline table

superheroes %>%
    semi_join(publishers, by = "publisher")
## # A tibble: 6 x 4
##   name     alignment gender publisher
##   <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <chr>    
## 1 Magneto  bad       male   Marvel   
## 2 Storm    good      female Marvel   
## 3 Mystique bad       female Marvel   
## 4 Batman   good      male   DC       
## 5 Joker    bad       male   DC       
## 6 Catwoman bad       female DC

Full Join

full_join(x, y): Return all rows and all columns from both x and y. Where there are not matching values, returns NA for the one missing. This is a mutating join.

superheroes %>%
    full_join(publishers, by = "publisher")
## # A tibble: 8 x 5
##   name     alignment gender publisher         yr_founded
##   <chr>    <chr>     <chr>  <chr>                  <int>
## 1 Magneto  bad       male   Marvel                  1939
## 2 Storm    good      female Marvel                  1939
## 3 Mystique bad       female Marvel                  1939
## 4 Batman   good      male   DC                      1934
## 5 Joker    bad       male   DC                      1934
## 6 Catwoman bad       female DC                      1934
## 7 Hellboy  good      male   Dark Horse Comics         NA
## 8 <NA>     <NA>      <NA>   Image                   1992

So far, all the logic basically follows what we have talked in the previous post

Question

  • What if column names in table A and table B are the same. How we gonna do for this situation.
  • what if the colname we wanna join has different names in two tables.

Let’s check out the different datatset

parts = readr::read_rds(url("https://assets.datacamp.com/production/repositories/5284/datasets/cb649926d41ce73490a9bb710e1501a273061723/parts.rds"))

parts_categories <- readr::read_rds(url("https://assets.datacamp.com/production/repositories/5284/datasets/30fc459770c89e46cce9cce99752ca95fb1d06fe/part_categories.rds"))

glimpse the data

Here we notice that both table parts and table parts_categories have col name called name

parts %>% head
## # A tibble: 6 x 3
##   part_num name                                                 part_cat_id
##   <chr>    <chr>                                                      <dbl>
## 1 0901     Baseplate 16 x 30 with Set 080 Yellow House Print              1
## 2 0902     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 Small White House Pr~           1
## 3 0903     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 Red House Print                 1
## 4 0904     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 Large White House Pr~           1
## 5 1        Homemaker Bookcase 2 x 4 x 4                                   7
## 6 10016414 Sticker Sheet #1 for 41055-1                                  58
parts_categories %>% head
## # A tibble: 6 x 2
##      id name                   
##   <dbl> <chr>                  
## 1     1 Baseplates             
## 2     3 Bricks Sloped          
## 3     4 Duplo, Quatro and Primo
## 4     5 Bricks Special         
## 5     6 Bricks Wedged          
## 6     7 Containers

Let’s pratcice. In this case we are told that part_cat_id and from parts and id from parts_categories are the two columns we want to join. In this case we need to specify which two colnames we wanna join.

parts %>%
    inner_join(parts_categories, by = c("part_cat_id" = "id")) %>% head # we need double quote in colname
## # A tibble: 6 x 4
##   part_num name.x                                     part_cat_id name.y   
##   <chr>    <chr>                                            <dbl> <chr>    
## 1 0901     Baseplate 16 x 30 with Set 080 Yellow Hou~           1 Baseplat~
## 2 0902     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 Small Whit~           1 Baseplat~
## 3 0903     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 Red House ~           1 Baseplat~
## 4 0904     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 Large Whit~           1 Baseplat~
## 5 1        Homemaker Bookcase 2 x 4 x 4                         7 Containe~
## 6 10016414 Sticker Sheet #1 for 41055-1                        58 Stickers

we find that inner join function aissgned two different names to the same colname from two table: name.x and name.y. we can specify the suffox in the name by doing so.

parts %>%
    inner_join(parts_categories, by = c("part_cat_id" = "id"),
               suffix = c("_parts", "_part_categoroes")) %>% head
## # A tibble: 6 x 4
##   part_num name_parts                        part_cat_id name_part_categor~
##   <chr>    <chr>                                   <dbl> <chr>             
## 1 0901     Baseplate 16 x 30 with Set 080 Y~           1 Baseplates        
## 2 0902     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 S~           1 Baseplates        
## 3 0903     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 R~           1 Baseplates        
## 4 0904     Baseplate 16 x 24 with Set 080 L~           1 Baseplates        
## 5 1        Homemaker Bookcase 2 x 4 x 4                7 Containers        
## 6 10016414 Sticker Sheet #1 for 41055-1               58 Stickers

Notice that the new table above keeps part_cat_id as column name since parts table works as the baseline table.

item.title: Tidyverse Join function Part-1
item.description:
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)

Introduction

This post serves as a learning record and practice with tidyverse package which is super awesome and convenient for data exploration and manipulation. PLease also check out this very help tutorial: https://stat545.com/join-cheatsheet.html

Let’s explore some fucntions in tidyverse for joining tables. And these functions basically follow same idea in SQL.

  • Inner Join (inner_join)
  • Left Join (left_join)
  • Right Join (right_join)
  • Full Join (full_join)
  • Semi Join (semi_join)
  • Anti Join (anti_join)

You may ask we already have SQL for doing this and why you need Tidyverse to do the same thing. This is because there’re lots of time you don’t have permissions to do so in database, or don’t want to ETL for one-off(single time) analysis, then utilising dplyr and R to join the data can prove to be more efficient.

tableA = tibble(
    CustomerID =  1:3,
    NumberOfOrder = c(5, 10, 4),
    TotalVolumeOrder = c(500, 240, 40),
    AverageVolumeOrder = c(100,24, 10),
    LastOrderDate = ymd(c("2017-10-01","2019-12-31", "2014-10-10"))
)

# or you can create a tibble like this using tribble
tableB <- tibble::tribble(
    
    ~CustomerID,  ~Age,  ~Gender,   ~FavouriteProduct,
    1L,           20L,       "Male",   "T-Shirt",
    2L,           23L,       "Female", "Legging",
    4L,           21L,       "Male",   "Jumpers"
)

tableA
## # A tibble: 3 x 5
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOrd~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>             <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500               100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240                24 2019-12-31   
## 3          3             4               40                10 2014-10-10
tableB
## # A tibble: 3 x 4
##   CustomerID   Age Gender FavouriteProduct
##        <int> <int> <chr>  <chr>           
## 1          1    20 Male   T-Shirt         
## 2          2    23 Female Legging         
## 3          4    21 Male   Jumpers

Inner Join

inner join will join same shared columns together within two tables, and we need to specify which column we wanna join. And here we use CutomerIDfor joining two tables together. For example, if we decided to join on Customer ID, the new table would contain rows 1 and 2:

tableA %>% 
    inner_join(tableB, by = 'CustomerID')
## # A tibble: 2 x 8
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOr~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>            <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500              100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240               24 2019-12-31   
## # ... with 3 more variables: Age <int>, Gender <chr>,
## #   FavouriteProduct <chr>

Notice that inner join makes sense when two columns are shared in both tables. Code below failed since join column NumberOfOrder which is missing from RHS => this is the tableB(RHS)

tableA %>% 
    inner_join(tableB, by = 'NumberOfOrder')
## `by` can't contain join column `NumberOfOrder` which is missing from RHS

Left Join

Left join will also combine two tables. However for this timee Left join will not make any change on table on the left. This also means that left table works as a baseline and we can add other columns from right table to the baseline table.

tableA
## # A tibble: 3 x 5
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOrd~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>             <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500               100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240                24 2019-12-31   
## 3          3             4               40                10 2014-10-10
tableA %>% 
    left_join(tableB, by = "CustomerID")
## # A tibble: 3 x 8
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOr~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>            <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500              100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240               24 2019-12-31   
## 3          3             4               40               10 2014-10-10   
## # ... with 3 more variables: Age <int>, Gender <chr>,
## #   FavouriteProduct <chr>

Here we have some NA Values since CustomerID = 3 in Left table doesn’t have information for Age, Gender, FavouriteProduct columns

Right Join

And Right Join basically follows the same logic which is the opposite of left join functtion

tableA
## # A tibble: 3 x 5
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOrd~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>             <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500               100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240                24 2019-12-31   
## 3          3             4               40                10 2014-10-10
tableB
## # A tibble: 3 x 4
##   CustomerID   Age Gender FavouriteProduct
##        <int> <int> <chr>  <chr>           
## 1          1    20 Male   T-Shirt         
## 2          2    23 Female Legging         
## 3          4    21 Male   Jumpers
tableA %>% 
    right_join(tableB, by = "CustomerID")
## # A tibble: 3 x 8
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOr~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>            <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500              100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240               24 2019-12-31   
## 3          4            NA               NA               NA NA           
## # ... with 3 more variables: Age <int>, Gender <chr>,
## #   FavouriteProduct <chr>

Full Join

Notice that table given by left join and right join are subset of table given by Full Join. Full join includes all the columns in tableA and tableB

tableA %>% 
    full_join(tableB, by = "CustomerID")
## # A tibble: 4 x 8
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOr~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>            <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500              100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240               24 2019-12-31   
## 3          3             4               40               10 2014-10-10   
## 4          4            NA               NA               NA NA           
## # ... with 3 more variables: Age <int>, Gender <chr>,
## #   FavouriteProduct <chr>

Anti Join

As we have seen when looking at creating training & test datasets for machine learning in dplyr, anti joins are super helpful. An anti join will return all of the rows from the first table where there are not matching values from the second. The new anti join table will only contain data from the first table, based on the join predicate listed above. An example of this is shown below:

tableA %>% 
    anti_join(tableB, by = "CustomerID")
## # A tibble: 1 x 5
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOrd~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>             <dbl> <date>       
## 1          3             4               40                10 2014-10-10

Basically table A works as a baseline table, and anti_join function will remove the row, which also appears in the table B, and return the remained row here.

Semi-join

And the last one is Semi-join. Let’s see how it works

tableA
## # A tibble: 3 x 5
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOrd~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>             <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500               100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240                24 2019-12-31   
## 3          3             4               40                10 2014-10-10
tableB
## # A tibble: 3 x 4
##   CustomerID   Age Gender FavouriteProduct
##        <int> <int> <chr>  <chr>           
## 1          1    20 Male   T-Shirt         
## 2          2    23 Female Legging         
## 3          4    21 Male   Jumpers
tableA %>% 
    semi_join(tableB, by = "CustomerID")
## # A tibble: 2 x 5
##   CustomerID NumberOfOrder TotalVolumeOrder AverageVolumeOrd~ LastOrderDate
##        <int>         <dbl>            <dbl>             <dbl> <date>       
## 1          1             5              500               100 2017-10-01   
## 2          2            10              240                24 2019-12-31

It works similar as inner join since it has two shared rows here. But we also notice that tableA works as baseline table and the new table does not have columns coming from tableB. we can think of it as we first do the inner_join to have a new_table, and then remove all the columns originating from table B.

Now check out part2 for join family in tidyverse
